\maketitle
\section{Introduction }
The study of complex networks is getting intensive. There are many scholars focusing on the formulation of complex network models.  Complex systems consist of many constituents such as individuals, substrates,
and companies in social, biological, and economic systems, respectively, showing cooperative phenomena between constituents through diverse interactions and adaptations to the pattern they create\cite{Barabasi-Albert1999}.  Watts and Strogatz \cite{Watts-DJ} analyzed a model for disordered networks and showed that they behave like a small-world model even for relatively small values of a disorder parameter.
The authors in literature \cite{ren-2015} pointed out that algorithm performance is analyzed theoretically for parallelism and errors, and numerical simulation results are presented to assess the
efficiency and effectiveness of distributed multiplicative Schwarz routing in achieving load balancing.

In \cite{Wang-zhao-Yao-2015}, the authors discussed an algorithm for finding the spanning trees with maximal leaves.
The literature \cite{Colman-2013} introduced a network evolution process motivated by the network of citations in the scientific literature. In each iteration of the process a vertex is born and directed links are
created from  new vertex to a set of target vertices already in the network.
To better understand the mechanism of power law formation in real world networks,  explore and analyze the underlying mechanism based on  vertex degree sequences of such networks\cite{Xiao-liu-chen-2014}.
In \cite{Zhang-Small-2015}, the authors proposed a simple maximum entropy process which provides the best representation of what are typical properties of scale-free networks, and furishes a standard against which real and algorithmically generated networks can be compared.

Power law distributions occur in many situations of scientific interest and have
significant consequences for our understanding of natural and man-made phenomena. Unfortunately,
the detection and characterization of power laws is complicated by the large fluctuations that occur
in the tail of the distribution the part of the distribution representing large but rare events and by the difficulty of identifying the range over which power law behavior retains. Commonly
used methods for analyzing power law data, such as least-squares fitting, can produce substantially
inaccurate estimates of parameters for power law distributions, and even in cases where such methods
return accurate answers they are still unsatisfactory because they give no indication of whether the
data obey a power law at all\cite{Aaron-Newman-2009}. Specifically, for one such site, the news aggregator, we show how a stochastic model distinguishes the effect of the increased visibility due to the network from how interested users are in the content. We find a wide range of interest, distinguishing stories primarily of interest
to users in the network (nice interests) from those of more general interest to the user community. This distinction is useful for predicting a story's eventual popularity from users early reactions to the story\cite{Kristina-2011}.

In this paper, we discover that there exists the equivalency of the cumulative degree distribution and edge-cumulative distribution. Furthermore,  we list three classical and famous network models of the recursive graphs, Sierpinksi networks and Apollonian networks to verify our conjecture:  Both the cumulative degree distribution and the edge-cumulative distribution are equivalent to each other in deterministic network models. Finally, we propose some directions for further research in order to provide guidance in our daily life.

\section{Cumulative  distributions}
The relationship between cumulative degree distribution and edge-cumulative distribution is indistinct and there is no way to know the connection. Currently, It exists two approaches to calculate  cumulative degree distribution and edge-cumulative distribution. The \emph{cumulative degree distribution} is defined as
$P_{cum}(k)=\sum_{k'>k}\frac{N(k', t)}{N(t)}\sim k^{1-\gamma}$ in\cite{Dorogovtsev-Goltsev-Mendes-2002}, where $N(t)$ denotes the total number of vertices at time step $t$,  $N(k', t)$ represents the number of vertices which the degree greater than $k$ at time step $t$.
Some literatures are drew support from this statistical approach\cite{Francesc-2004, Zhang-zhou-2007,  Zhang-Francesc-2005}.
The \emph{edge-cumulative distribution} is defined as $P_{ecum}(k)=\sum_{k'>k}\frac{E(k', t)}{E(t)}\sim k^{1-\gamma}$ in \cite{Liu-Yao-Zhang-2014}, where $E(t)$ denotes the total number of edges at time step $t$,  $E(k', t)$ stands for the number of edges which the degree greater than $k$ at time step $t$. The distinction between cumulative distribution and edge-cumulative distribution is that the denominator of the expression stands for different implication. While $P_{cum}(k)$, $P_{ecum}(k)$ are applied to the total number of vertices and  edges of the network, respectively.  Besides,  the numerator in a fraction also possess diverse messages in $P_{cum}(k)$ and $P_{ecum}(k)$, the former denotes the number of vertices with degree greater than $k$ at time step $t$; the latter represent the number of edges with degree greater than $k$ at time step $t$.  Here $k$ and $k'$ are points of the discrete degree spectrum. Both of them can be regarded a criteria to illustrate the network with scale-free behavior. Furthermore, what connection exists between them? We conjecture that two distributions are  equivalent to each other.




\section{Testifying the equivalence of two cumulative distributions}
In order to validate the equivalence of  cumulative degree distribution and edge-cumulative distribution, we  introduce several classical scale-free network models to explain our conjecture.

\subsection{Recursive graphs $K(q,t)$}
Now we apply an  algorithm to  illustrate the  construction of recursive graphs. Some properties of recursive graphs $K(q,t)$ have been discussed in \cite{Francesc-2004}.
{\small
\begin{algorithm}
\caption{\textbf{N-algorithm}}\label{}
\begin{algorithmic}
\STATE \emph{\textbf{Initialization.}} $K(q,0)$ is a complete graph $K_q$ of $q$ vertices.
\STATE \emph{\textbf{Operation.}} Add a new vertex  for each of its existing subgraphs isomorphic to a $q$-clique and join it with all vertices of the subgraph.  For example, at $t=1$, add a new vertex and join it with all vertices of $K(q,0)$, which forms a $(q+1)$-clique.
\STATE \emph{\textbf{Iteration.}}  $K(q,t)$ is obtained from $K(q,t-1)$
by adding for each of its existing subgraphs isomorphic to a  $q$-clique a new vertex in order to form a $(q+1)$-clique.
\end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm}
}

Let $\Delta^{N}_{v}(t), \Delta^{N}_{e}(t)$ be the numbers of vertices and edges of $K(q,t)$ created at time step $t$. According to the construction of  recursive graphs $K(q,t)$,  it is easily to compute the values of $\Delta^{N}_{v}(t), \Delta^{N}_{e}(t)$  in the way $\Delta^{N}_{v}(t)=(q+1)^{t-1}, \Delta^{N}_{v}(t)=q(q+1)^{t-1}$. The notation $n_v(t), n_e(t)$ represent the total numbers of vertices and edges at time step $t$, respectively.  Furthermore, we can compute the size and order of the recursive graph $K(q,t)$ as follows

nexttext: At time $t$, the degree spectrum of the Sierpinski  network model $S(t)$ is as: $n_d(t)=3\cdot6^{t-1}, 3\cdot6^{t-2}, 3\cdot6^{t-3},\cdots , 6$ when  $d=4,3^{2}+1,3^{3}+1,\dots, 3^{t}+1$.  We can observe that the degree spectrum of the network model is discrete. Other values of degree are absent. It is easily to obtain cumulative degree distribution of Sierpinski network model is given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle s_{v}(t)&\displaystyle=\sum^{t}\limits_{j=0}\Delta^%
{S}_{v}(j)=\frac{3\cdot 6^{t}+12}{5}\\
\displaystyle s_{e}(t)&\displaystyle=\sum^{t}\limits_{j=0}\Delta^{S}_{e}(j)=%
\frac{9\cdot 6^{t}+6}{5}\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>v</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></munderover><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>S</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mn>6</mn><mi>t</mi></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow><mn>5</mn></mfrac></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></munderover><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>S</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>j</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mn>6</mn><mi>t</mi></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mn>5</mn></mfrac></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

\frac{d(d+1)}{2}+\sum^{t}\limits_{j=1}(d+1)^{j}\\

prevtext: The degree spectrum of the network model is discrete since $n_d(t)=1, d+1, (d+1)^{2}, \dots , (d+1)^{t-1}$ with $d=(d+1)(\sum^{t-2}_{j=0}d^{j}+1), (d+1)(\sum^{t-3}_{j=0}d^{j}+1), (d+1)(\sum^{t-4}_{j=0}d^{j}+1), \dots ,d+1$. Other values of degree are absent. According to the degree spectrum of the Apollonian network model, we can compute the cumulative degree distribution of Apollonian network model is given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle P^{A}_{cum}(k)&\displaystyle=\frac{1}{a_{v}(t)}\sum%
^{\tau}\limits_{i=0}\Delta^{A}_{v}(i)\\
&\displaystyle=\frac{d(d+1)+(d+1)^{\tau}-1}{d(d+1)+(d+1)^{t}-1}\\
&\displaystyle=(d+1)^{\tau-t}\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mi>A</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>v</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>τ</mi></munderover><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>A</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>τ</mi></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>t</mi></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>
